body: @vjagadish1989 This should fix the integration test!

@sborya I have made the changes. Please review. Thanks!

@xinyuiscool : can you also review this ?

Due to [INFRA-13775](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-13775), I will verify "gradlew build" passes locally before committing. 

Thanks!
@xinyuiscool Please take a look when you get a chance.

Is there a JIRA associated with this PR? 

> There were issues with bootstrapping from CoordinatorStream

What were the issues with bootstrapping? 

Whatever was the problem with bootstrapping, did it exist from before or was it introduced recently due to some change?

Hi @shanthoosh,

Thanks for the patch. 

Some questions / observations here:

1.
>> One BrokerProxy is created for a kafkaCluster (Host, Port) combination and shared by all KafkaSystemConsumer instances.

It's my understanding that Broker proxy threads are not shared across `KafkaSystemConsumer` instances. @jmakes / @navina can correct me.

2.
>> BrokerProxy for each (Host, Port) is stopped in KafkaSystemConsumer.stop and not recreated during successive KafkaSystemConsumer.create calls.

This is by design and should be always true. 

3.
>> Altering the KafkaSystemConsumer.create logic to recreate BrokerProxy
for each (Host, Port) impacts other portions of KafkaSystemConsumer

Wondering why this option is even worth considering? Maybe, I don't understand what problem we are solving?

4. 
>>  hence for now this patch removes the coordinatorSystemConsumer.stop call from finally block
in classes JobModelManager and SamzaTaskProxy.

I don't like stopping the producer and not the consumer asymmetrically. So, I'm -1 for solutions like these that complicate lifecycle management.

5.

>> There were issues with bootstrapping from CoordinatorStream because of the problem described above. This change resolves them.

What were the issues and is there a test to reproduce this? How does not stopping the consumer fix them? 

6. Is this a regression? If so, wondering which commit/feature introduced it?
@prateekm Thanks for the review. I addressed all your comments and rebased branch against master. Could you please take a look?

@vjagadish1989  @navina 

Here is the detailed explanation of why I’m proposing to remove coordinatorStreamConsumer.stop, coordinatorStreamProducer.stop in JobModelManager.

> Problem: 

During AM startup, me & @xinyuiscool noticed that when we stop coordinatorStreamConsumer after 
jobModel is generated in JobModelManager, future reads from the coordinatorStream in AM doesn’t read until the highest watermark offset. 
Subsequents coordinatorStream consumption was until the last offset held in the cache(BlockingEnvelopeMap) of KafkaConsumer. 
We also noticed from the logs that the BrokerProxy was getting started only once and after call to coordinatorStreamConsumer.stop doesn’t start again before coordinator stream read.

@vjagadish1989 : 

For points 1,2,3 of your comment.

I misunderstood that BrokerProxy was shared by all KafkaSystemConsumer and felt that this is the reason why subsequent coordinator stream reads was not returning messages till highest offset.

For point 6 : 
> Why this change was made? Where was it introduced?  

As a part of JobModelManager refactoring, I added coordinatorStreamConsumer.stop, coordinatorStreamProducer.stop  in the finally block of JobModelManager.apply method. 

Reason for doing it : These resources(coordinatorStreamConsumer, coordinatorStreamProducer) were created in the apply method and most of them goes out of scope after the method execution. 

With the intent to handle the lifecycle and free up resources, this change was done. 

A BrokerProxy thread is spawned for each KafkaSystemConsumer creation. 

And a KafkaSystemConsumer is created for each call to JobModelManager.apply. After the completion,  kind of felt this is unnecessary to leave this thread open, when it will be unused.

> What is the actual cause of this? Why was messages are not read till highest watermark offset? 

In jobModel creation, localityManager is passed in as a parameter and is used for reading ContainerLocality mappings.

Passing in a live resource(that holds open socket connections, threads) to a pojo object that should’ve been immutable kinds of now creates a global state dependency. 

Since the reference to both coordinatorStreamConsumer, coordinatorStreamProducer is held indirectly through jobModel(a client which has jobModel reference can get stale data if getContainerLocality is invoked after coordinatorStreamConsumer.close), it doesn’t make sense to stop them just after generating the jobModel.

In SamzaContainerProcessManager.start, we read containerToHostMappings from the jobModel, which in turn uses localityManager to read from it. 

Since the systemConsumer is closed after the job model creation , this read containerLocality just returns the messages to be returned only from the KafkaConsumer cache.

 
> Ideal fix would entail doing the following. 

* To handle lifecycle properly, should be just passing the container locality map(map<String, map<String, String>) in jobModel constructor during creation, which is beyond the scope of this patch. 
* Fixing the BalancingTaskNameGrouper interface which takes in localityManager. Since samza users can indirectly reference(coordinatorStreamConsumer, coordinatorStreamProducer)   in their taskNameGrouper implementation and can have logic based upon that. This interface needs to change before we can conclusively say lifecycle of this resource is now done.  


> I don't like stopping the producer and not the consumer asymmetrically.

 I’m not stopping both coordinatorStreamConsumer, coordinatorStreamProducer in it. 

> -1 for complicating lifecycle management. 

This was how it was before my refactoring. This  complication was introduced because of how jobModel was constructed which existed much prior to JobModelManager refactoring.  

Moreover, this is not a permanent fix to this problem. Just a interim solution to unblock @xinyuiscool testing, before we fix it properly. 

@vjagadish1989 if you’re still not convinced, we can discuss this offline.
@xinyuiscool : Can you please take a look when you're free.

@santhoshvenkat1988 I thought we discussed this in the morning. Before I respond to your comments, can you please move the description of the problem and its proposed solution to a JIRA? PR is not a place to be doing root-cause analysis. Please read [the docs](http://samza.apache.org/contribute/contributors-corner.html#contributing-to-apache-samza)

>  when we stop coordinatorStreamConsumer after jobModel is generated in JobModelManager, future reads from the coordinatorStream in AM doesn’t read until the highest watermark offset.

Which component is doing the "future reads" ? Afaik, the leader creates the JobModel and exposes it using the HTTP end-point. even though the goal is for the leader to continuously catch-up with coordinator stream, I don't believe we are doing that yet. Correct me if I am wrong.

>In jobModel creation, localityManager is passed in as a parameter and is used for reading ContainerLocality mappings.
> 
> Passing in a live resource(that holds open socket connections, threads) to a pojo object that should’ve been immutable kinds of now creates a global state dependency.

Agreed. 

>  it doesn’t make sense to stop them just after generating the jobModel.

That makes sense. But how are you proposing to fix this? Not handling life-cycle within JobModelManager and pushing it up to the callers is a fine model too. It doesn't look like that is what is in the patch though.

> To handle lifecycle properly, should be just passing the container locality map(map<String, map<String, String>) in jobModel constructor during creation, which is beyond the scope of this patch.

It seems like you have identified a real issue here. However, I disagree on the fix being outside the scope of this patch. In fact, this PR seems to have identified a good deal of issues we have. But it doesn't address any of them, leaving behind loopholes. -1 on the scoping of the issue/patch

> This interface needs to change before we can conclusively say lifecycle of this resource is now done.

It is not straightforward to change a public interface. Please create a SEP or at the very least a JIRA for everyone to understand why you are proposing this change. 

> This was how it was before my refactoring. This complication was introduced because of how jobModel was constructed which existed much prior to JobModelManager refactoring.

It is awesome that you have identified a crucial bug/issue. Rather than taking it back to the broken state that it was, I prefer to fix it forward. 

> Just a interim solution to unblock @xinyuiscool testing, before we fix it properly.

What part of this fix is @xinyuiscool blocked on?

Overall, I don't understand the basis behind the solution in this PR. -1 for this change. Please create a JIRA for further discussions. Thanks!

This is the fix for the coordinator stream bootstrap hanging issue in appmaster. The bug is introduced by the JobCoordinator refactoring patch, which closes the coordinator consumer/producer prematurely (they are still being used later by locality manager). Since a clean approach to solve this problem is a much larger scope and requires more testing, I think it's okey to revert to old logic. With this fix, 0.13 testing can be unblocked.

I completely agree we need a JIRA to clearly say what's the problem we have right now and why we are making this change for now. And we should have another JIRA tracking the future cleanup. @shanthoosh : could you please create the JIRAs?

@navina 

Due to losing access to my dev machine & losing stored passwords for all website accounts because of that,  was unable to create the JIRA(wasn't able to login to JIRA). Now recovering access, will update it here once done.

> I think it's okey to revert to old logic

From what I understand, reverting this logic doesn't solve the core issues identified through this PR discussion. What testing in 0.13 are we talking about if we don't fix known issues? May be it is related to the upcoming MVP release date. But I am not comfortable releasing a version with known bugs. 

>Now recovering access, will update it here once done.

Thank you.

@navina: the bug introduced previously is actually a major blocker issue. Samza jobs hang in yarn because of this (no testing can be done based on the master branch). I think we need a fix asap. After that @shanthoosh  can work on a proper fix, which can still be in the 0.13 release.

@navina 
Updated PR with JIRA created. Can you take a look when you're free.
@vjagadish1989  @prateekm : can you guys please review ? Thanks!
Yep. It is being followed up in separate JIRAs. Thanks!
@vjagadish1989 Thanks for the review! Can we merge and close this PR?
@vjagadish1989 can we merge and close this PR?
@logarithm Thank you for the patch, committed! Looking forward to more contributions :-)
@vjagadish1989 Thanks!
Anything left for me to do?  Happy to make more changes.  I realize this is a low priority issue - just a configuration convenience for our specific use case.

@nickpan47 I have addressed all your comments. Please let me know if anything pending.

@jmakes  @vjagadish1989 : Can you guys take a look at those classes I have assigned to you guys?

@xinyuiscool @navina 

Please take a look when you get a chance.

> (When EOS message is used a final msg, during some runs task.process gets invoked more than once for it. This is due to test setup, other tests within this test class also do the same.

Why does the test setup invoke task.process more than once when EOS message is used?

Isn't SAMZA-1183 supposed to address testProcessInOrder test as well that was commented out?
@fredji97 Looks like there are some conflicts. Can we please resolve them?

@navina 
> Isn't SAMZA-1183 supposed to address testProcessInOrder test as well that was commented out?

Ideally, sync commit tests(testProcessInOrder) shouldn't be affected. Code associated with them aren't modified for ages. @xinyuiscool can correct me here, if i'm wrong. Despite that we're seeing failures. Success/Failure of individual tests depends upon proper initialization of shared global state in before method.  In parallel execution of tests, assignments can get interleaved leading to race conditions. 

As a fix I've moved object hierarchy construction to individual test methods & local build's green.

> Why does the test setup invoke task.process more than once when EOS message is used?

I should have phrased that better. 

There's a lag between processing last message & shutting the executor down in tests(This was allowed since in some runs executor is shutdown before task threads complete). Due to which, the last value returned by the mock will be the value it returns throughout the lag period(this is how mocks work). So it keeps on hitting task.process method with that EOS message. When chooser returns null as last value(instead of EOS), AsyncRunLoop doesn’t hit task instances(hence the change).
@jmakes and @prateekm : please take a look at this patch. Thanks.

@prateekm : I think I also fixed the stuff you mentioned in your early feedback. As we discussed, NodeId is the ID for either operator node or stream node, and it is used to construct the topology of the graph. For rendering, stream is also a node in this json graph (we will start from the source stream). For join, now two operator nodes are created to keep it in sync with StreamGraph. Each node has a reference of the other in the pair. I updated the link to the example json. Please take a look again.
@xinyuiscool & @nickpan47 : Can you guys please take a look at this PR? Thanks!

> As a fix I've moved object hierarchy construction to individual test methods & local build's green.

Whether the test has been modified recently or not, a failure is something we need to fix. By moving the object hierarchy construction, are you also addressing the testProcessInOrder failures? That is my question. 

> There's a lag between processing last message & shutting the executor down in tests(This was allowed since in some runs executor is shutdown before task threads complete). Due to which, the last value returned by the mock will be the value it returns throughout the lag period(this is how mocks work). So it keeps on hitting task.process method with that EOS message. When chooser returns null as last value(instead of EOS), AsyncRunLoop doesn’t hit task instances(hence the change).

I have tried to condense your verbose comment into what I understand - Basically, the mock consumer used was causing the EOS to be delivered more than once, when the executor was shutdown before task threads complete.  
Hence, my follow-up question is - Why is the executor shutdown before the tasks complete? Is that the expected behavior?

@navina 

Discussed with you offline.
> By moving the object hierarchy construction, are you also addressing the testProcessInOrder failures? That is my question.

Code & tests associated with it are unchanged for very long time, hence surprising to see failures. Yes, it will fix it(no common global state shared by test methods which is potential cause).

> Why is the executor shutdown before the tasks complete? Is that the expected behavior?

Yes, task threads might take more time to finish. Shutting down executor before it, will cause assertion failure(depending upon the timing of events). The change I want to test is AsyncTaskState state transition, however everything within AsyncRunLoop(AsyncTaskState) is private(Changing that would be harder) and all other tests follow the same pattern. Modifying them would be a harder & bigger change(may be we can create a JIRA for it to work in future)
@vjagadish1989 thanks I resolved the conflicts. Please let me know if you have any question.
I merged @prateekm 's recent patch and addressed all the comments. Please take a look again. Thanks!
btw, also updated the example json here (https://github.com/xinyuiscool/examples/blob/master/example_plan.json).

> It "generates" some containerIds according to the count. It receives others from external sources like the task assignment manager. I was only suggesting that the latter should be validated s.t. we throw an exception rather than letting unexpected/undefined behavior occur.

Yeah. I agree we can test the latter. The place where you had added the comment threw me off. It should probably be in getPreviousContainers, where we readTaskAssignment.

> Also, I believe this is not equivalent to integer comparison.
In a sort scenario, for the same id's:
Integer comparison would yield [3, 8, 10]
String comparison would yield [10, 3, 8]
We should be certain that this will not affect any other code that uses ContainerModel as a comparator. e.g. for sort. If that code expects them to be in integer order for example, it could break. Or it could produce inconsistent behavior, different mappings of anything that is assigned to containers in a round-robin fashion.

I totally agree that comparison between Integer and String will result in different order. I am actually not even sure if "comparable" even makes sense anymore. I am trying to figure out where in our code we rely on "ordering" or "sorting" of ContainerModels. I couldn't find any use-case for this. 
In fact, I removed it and ran a build and it seems to work fine. However, that may not be sufficient as our test coverage is pretty poor :(
@xinyuiscool you should have some familiarity with these changes. They're a direct copy from the prototype.
@fredji97 : Thanks for the patch, Merged, and submitted to master. Can you please close the associated JIRA with the fix version?

@jmakes @nickpan47 I have updated based on the feedback. Hopefully,I didn't miss any related to this SEP. Most recent changes:
* updated the documentation in ProcessorIdGenerator and ApplicationConfig
* Added validation in GroupByContainerCount
* Removed compareTo in ContainerModel
@xinyuiscool  Removed physical wait(Thread.sleep) from TestAsyncRunLoop. Build is red due to  TestJmxReporter failures(unrelated to this change)
@shanthoosh This doesn't remove the wait, only the Thread.sleep(). I still see `callbackExecutor.awaitTermination(600, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS);`.

@prateekm  

You're right. 

Removing callbackExecutor.await from all tests & testing just the behavior, if i understand right would involve the following changes.

* Changing access specifier for testable internal class/methods to protected.
* Changing all tests(which do this) in TestAsyncRunLoop to achieve uniformity. 

Is it okay to create JIRA & solve it later.

I have tested with an integration test (https://github.com/xinyuiscool/examples/blob/master/TestZkLocalApplicationRunner.java). Tried partionBy() and map() and then sendTo(). All works now.

I will add unit tests to this soon.

> Is it okay to create JIRA & solve it later.

The goal of the JIRA is to fix the tests (flaky or not) in TestAsyncRunloop. I don't see a lot of value in postponing this task in yet another "fix test" JIRA. I would rather implement the right fix now rather than later, while we have context on what the correct implementation is.

@navina 

> The goal of the JIRA is to fix the tests (flaky or not) in TestAsyncRunloop. I don't see a lot of value in postponing this task in yet another "fix test" JIRA. 

The goal was to actually fix the flaky test as described in the JIRA(removing wait is unnecessary to accomplish that). 

However, it makes sense to remove awaitTermination(physical wait) here(since it will wait 'x' seconds every time, even though all the task threads finishes before that within the test). 

I've an idea(which I think will work), will discuss it with xinyu(since it will touch all tests in this class) and update it here.

> I've an idea(which I think will work), will discuss it with xinyu(since it will touch all tests in this class) and update it here.

Sounds good. Let's not carry over tech-debts. Thanks 👍

@navina

Please take a look when you get a chance.

@navina 
Done. Fixed Jira number.

> No matter what implementation a JobCoordinator class takes, as long as it is loading ProcessorIdGenerator implementation, it should use the loader method and will perform this validation.

Our config validations are usually encapsulated in the corresponding "Config" class. Here, we are simply testing this for compatibility with existing streamprocessor users. Since it is temporary, I think it should be fine.
@nickpan47 I updated the JIRA ticket with comments.
@jmakes @nickpan47 @prateekm Please can you guys take a pass at this?
Looks like I need to rebase my change.  Builds fine in my dev branch, but, when I apply the changes to the latest version of master I can reproduce the problem above.  Investigating.
I consolidated the processorId generation part into StreamProcessor constructor, and then pass it into Coordinator and ContainerController. Now the logic should be much cleaner.

Rebased the commit on top of master (260414d) and fixed the two resulting new compile issues with the unit tests (how the MapConfig is now initialized from a Properties instance) and the pre-checks now pass.
@xinyuiscool Can you please review this PR ?
Thanks @nickpan47. I don't have perm to merge this. I assume someone who has will merge this?

> I consolidated the processorId generation part into StreamProcessor constructor, and then pass it into Coordinator and ContainerController. Now the logic should be much cleaner.

I am currently working on refactoring the interaction between StreamProcessor/JobCoordinator/Container. I think the goal is for the StreamProcessor to listen to JobCoordinator events and accordingly, manage the container lifecycle. This way, we de-couple jobcoordinator from container lifecycle. While it makes sense for processorId to come from StreamProcessor to make it for LocalApplicationRunner, I think the change to JobCoordinatorFactory to include processorId is incorrect and should have been called out explicitly in the PR. 

In future, please document motivations for changing samza-core apis as well. It impacts other developers relying on the samza-core interface. 

In general, please seek for explicit approvals from committers who have explicitly given a -1 in the PR before committing the code. While it defies the general [commit policy](https://www.apache.org/foundation/voting.html#votes-on-code-modification) followed in Apache projects, more importantly, it impacts the productivity of other project developers, and ultimately, the progress of the project itself. Thanks!

Apologies for committing it before +1 form everyone in the reviews. Chatted with @navina offline and this patch is the first attempt to define the contract between ApplicationRunner and StreamProcessor. @navina will have a much better implementation of the life cycle management of StreamProcessor and its components.
Merged. Thanks!
@prateekm @xinyuiscool @nickpan47 Changes based on what I proposed in slack. Review please!
@xinyuiscool @nickpan47 Also, looks like LocalApplicationRunner is managing StreamProcessor directly. Is the plan to add the (no-op) LocalJobRunner layer later? If not, can we update SEP-2?

Could it be related to the code section you put into the summary field here?

@prateekm I thought `joinRetainsMatchedMessagesReverse` was failing intermittently. How is advancing clock time on other tests going to fix this? Are the tests related?

@navina The clock time in those tests needs to advanced by an amount larger than TTL (100 ms == 10 times TTL of 10 ms). Since I increased the TTL to 1 minute, that amount now needs to be higher. I just rewrote that amount explicitly in terms of the TTL.

@vjagadish1989 this one fixes the stream config bug and re-introduces the deprecated configs into the table

btw, I also changed the status computation for RemoteApplicationRunner to be consistent with LocalApplicationRunner. So now it follows the following logic:

- status is **new** if there are new jobs which are not started
- status is **running** if all jobs are started and some are running
- status is **unsuccessfulFinished** if all jobs are finished and some fail
- status is **successfulFinished** if all jobs are finished successfully

@prateekm @xinyuiscool I have addressed all the comments. Only exception is the one involving the boolean flag. Replacing it with the enum makes it easy to read. But I don't think we have clear values for the enum - except for JobCoordinator. 
On second thought, would it be better to keep a separate method called "pause" in SamzaContainer and that is used to set the paused flag. The benefit of this approach is: 
1. It will be more readable and we won't semantically overload the shutdown method
2. In future, when we refactor container to have a well-defined paused status, it should be relatively simple to transition over. 

What do you think?
Fixed code based on comments. Let me know if there is anything else.
